title: Astros closer Josh Hader lands on IL in ‘punch to the gut’
description: The Astros’ injury woes got even worse on Tuesday.
content:
The Astros’ injury woes got even worse on Tuesday.

The franchise placed closer Josh Hader on the 15-day injured list with a left shoulder strain, adding to their long list of sidelined players.

Hader, 31, reportedly felt some shoulder discomfort Monday and wasn’t available to pitch during their 7-6 win over the Red Sox.

“He walked in and he was doing his [plyometrics] before doing his throwing program and just did not feel right,” Astros manager Joe Espada said, according to MLB.com. “We went ahead and got some testing done, and we’re waiting on the results and should know something more tomorrow.”

On Friday against the Yankees, Hader threw a season-high 36 pitches over two innings, which was the last time he entered a game.

Hader warmed up in the bullpen on Sunday but didn’t get into the game.

“A punch to the gut,” manager Espada said of the news on Tuesday, according to The Athletic.

Hader had been his usual dominant self before the injury this season, logging 28 saves with a 2.05 ERA in 48 games.

Espada said he’s not ready to name another closer just yet.

“I’m not naming [anyone] for the ninth, not naming [anyone] for the eighth,” he said.

Hader is the eighth pitcher to join the Astros’ current injured list, which includes starters Luis Garcia and Lance McCullers Jr.

Position players such as Yordan Alvarez, Jake Meyers and Isaac Paredes are also out with various ailments.

The Astros have had some good news when it comes to the health of their starting rotation of late, though, after they welcomed back Cristian Javier and Spencer Arrighetti from the injured list.

Heading into Tuesday’s play, the Astros are 67-52 and clinging to a one-game lead over the Mariners in the American League West.
summary: The Houston Astros have placed closer Josh Hader on the 15-day injured list due to a left shoulder strain, adding to their long list of sidelined players. Hader reportedly felt discomfort and was not available to pitch during their 7-6 win over the Red Sox. Despite this, manager Joe Espada described the news as a "punch to the gut" and not yet ready to name another closer. This adds to the team's injury woes, with Cristian Javier and Spencer Arrighetti returning from the injured list.
shortSummary: The Astros' injury woes worsened as Josh Hader was placed on the 15-day injured list with a shoulder strain, adding to their current woes.

scraped_sources.text:
HOUSTON — Add another injury to a Houston Astros season defined by them.
The Astros placed All-Star closer Josh Hader on the injured list Tuesday, one day after he reported shoulder discomfort and did not pitch in a save situation against the Boston Red Sox.
“A punch to the gut,” manager Joe Espada said before Tuesday’s game against the Red Sox.
Advertisement
The Astros described Hader’s injury as a left-shoulder strain and backdated his IL stint to Aug. 11. According to Espada, Hader was seeing doctors and getting additional testing done on Tuesday afternoon to determine the severity of his injury.
The team recalled Colton Gordon from Triple A to take Hader’s spot on the active roster and reinstated right-hander Shawn Dubin from the injured list to further fortify the bullpen. Veteran Héctor Neris was designated for assignment.
Hader, 31, has never been on the injured list during his nine-year major-league career aside from a stint on the COVID-19 IL in August 2021 after he tested positive for the virus.
According to Espada, Hader experienced pain in his shoulder after completing some of his plyometric work prior to Monday’s game. Hader warmed up to pitch in Sunday’s game at Yankee Stadium, but went unused after the Astros scored three runs to widen their lead and eliminate a save situation.
Hader last appeared on Friday against the Yankees, throwing two innings and a season-high 36 pitches during the Astros’ 5-3, extra-inning win.
Once opposed to throwing multiple innings earlier in his career, Hader has softened his stance since signing a five-year, $95 million contract last winter. Hader has thrown multiple innings in 14 of his 119 regular-season outings as an Astro.
Asked whether Hader recovered normally after Friday’s outing, Espada replied, “He played catch (on Saturday) and then I got him up on Sunday. Everything was fine until yesterday, he came in and was doing his warmup, and it did not feel right.”
Hader has converted 28 of his 29 save chances during a dominant season that produced his sixth All-Star selection. His 28 saves trail only San Diego’s Robert Suárez and Kansas City’s Carlos Estévez for the major-league lead.
Advertisement
Hader’s 2.05 ERA is lower than those of Suárez and Estévez. Among American League closers, only Seattle’s Andrés Muñoz and Boston’s Aroldis Chapman have lower ERAs than Hader.
Hader has appeared in 42 of the Astros’ first 67 wins while only throwing in six losses, underscoring his importance to a team that thrives on its run prevention and execution in close games. The Astros entered Tuesday with a 21-12 record in one-run games and 56-1 when leading after eight innings, two marks that are a testament to Hader’s dominance.
On Tuesday, Espada resisted assigning any defined roles in Hader’s absence. Set-up man Bryan Abreu, he of a 1.67 ERA and 13.1 strikeouts per nine innings, is the most obvious option to take closing duties in Hader’s absence, but Espada maintained, “I’m not naming (anyone) for the ninth, not naming (anyone) for the eighth.”
“I was talking to the relievers about this. Josh Hader, (for) how successful he’s been, he needs guys to give him the ball with the lead in the ninth. All these guys have set him up to be the closer that he is,” Espada said. “Not taking anything away from Josh — Josh is probably the best — but you need guys to help him get to that point. These guys are capable of doing that.”
In the absence of established roles, Espada will take a matchup-based approach for however long Hader is sidelined.
Even in Hader’s absence, Houston has a lefty-heavy bullpen that has bullied right-handed hitters all season — giving Espada myriad options late in games.
Entering Tuesday, Astros left-handed relievers had faced 583 right-handed hitters and limited them to a .593 OPS. Dubin is a hard-throwing right-handed option who can contribute multiple innings.
Ditto for newcomer Enyel De Los Santos, who started the ninth inning of a one-run game on Monday in Hader’s absence. Southpaw Bennett Sousa finished it, striking out Roman Anthony to strand the tying run at second base.
Advertisement
“What you guys saw yesterday, piecing it together, we’re going to have to do more of that,” Espada said on Tuesday.
Hader joins seven other Astros pitchers on an injured list that has grown as large as 18 players during this star-crossed season. Within the past week, starters Cristian Javier and Spencer Arrighetti have returned from long-term injuries, which was encouraging news for the team’s overall pitching health. Hader’s shoulder discomfort now diminishes that progress.
(Photo: Tim Warner / Getty Images)

CBS reporter Amanda Balionis enjoyed some R&R in Ibiza before she hits the sidelines for the 2025 NFL season.
Taking to Instagram, Balionis shared a carousel of snapshots from the trip she took with her grade school friends and their partners.
“Hey Ibiza.. It was really nice to meet ya 🤝 Never take for granted that many of my best friends are the ones I met in elementary school,” Balionis, 39, captioned the Saturday post. “To take this trip with them… well I think 5th grade us would be really proud of how far we’ve come, and that we continue to choose to do it together ❤️❤️ also shoutout to the guys for marrying the most fun partners 🫡.”
Balionis looked stunning in a white bikini as she enjoyed a coconut cocktail under the sun.
Other images spotlighted group dinners, sightseeing and partying in fluorescent-lit clubs.
Balionis took some well-deserved time off after 19 weeks on the road with “Golf on CBS.”
Last week, she shared a tribute to her broadcast team, including photos from the season.
“Hard to put into words what 19 weeks on the road really looks like,” Balionis wrote. “For us announcers, we have it easy — we show up to work with hotel rooms already booked, everything we need waiting at check-in. Our headsets and mics work flawlessly, our sets are stocked, and our camera operators have been setting the scene for days.”
Balionis made headlines off the course last May when a Daily Mail report linked her and McIlroy after he filed for divorce from his wife of seven years, Erica Stoll.
McIlroy, 36, and Stoll have since reunited, and his divorce petition was voluntarily dismissed.
Fans noticed Balionis wasn’t wearing her wedding ring last February while covering the Genesis Invitational.
Balionis married former North Carolina quarterback Bryn Renner, who also had a brief career in the NFL, in 2022.
Balionis, who wasn’t wearing her ring in the Ibiza photos, has not publicly addressed speculation about a divorce, but Renner no longer appears on her social media pages.
Us Weekly confirmed last spring that Balinois and the reigning Masters champ “are not dating and only have a professional relationship.”
Balionis joined CBS Sports in 2017 as a golf reporter and also serves as a sideline reporter for select NFL ON CBS games and CBS Sports Network college football games.

argos_summary: The Houston Astros have placed closer Josh Hader on the 15-day injured list due to a left shoulder strain, adding to their growing list of injured players. Hader experienced discomfort after a workout and had not pitched in a game against the Red Sox. This season, he has been highly effective, recording 28 saves with a 2.05 ERA, but his absence raises concerns for the team's bullpen as they navigate a challenging season marked by injuries.
